poem:
**Winter's Arithmetic**  

Chill bites deeper,  
in numbers—  
rising quiet on page  
and purse—  
a furnace's breath  
in the grip of grey,  
we count warmth  
in percentages,  
small flames of fear  
flicker through  
January,  
a climb  
to 3.7,  
we feel the weight  
of digits as they  
heat our homes  
and empty  
our hands.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Chill of inflation threatens Britain again after Europe’s long, hard winter A scramble to heat homes during a cold winter across Europe has sent gas prices soaring from where they were six months ago. This week, that extra cost will appear in figures that City analysts say will show inflation jumped to 2.8% in January, from 2.5% in December and 1.7% last September. The Bank of England says inflation will keep rising towards 3.7% this". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
